fast_ice_processorÔÉÅ

class fast_ice_processor.FastIceProcessor(sim_name, json_path=None, roll_win=None, P_log=None)[source]ÔÉÅ

Bases: object

Class to compute Fast Ice metrics from sea ice model output.

This processor applies a rolling window to compute spatial and temporal characteristics of fast ice using sea ice concentration and velocity thresholds.

Fast ice is defined as sea ice with concentration above a threshold and velocity below a threshold (i.e., stationary sea ice).

Parameters:

  • sim_name (str) ‚Äì Name of the simulation (used to resolve directory paths and configuration).

  • json_path (str, optional) ‚Äì Path to the JSON configuration file. If None, the default config is used.

  • roll_win (int, optional) ‚Äì Rolling window size in days (default is 15 or value specified in config).

  • P_log (str or Path, optional) ‚Äì Path to output log file. Defaults to logs/FastIceProcessor_{sim_name}.log.

configÔÉÅ

Full configuration dictionary loaded from JSON.

Type:

dict

roll_winÔÉÅ

Length of the rolling window in days.

Type:

int

List of variable names to extract from CICE history files.

Type:

Grid and landmask handler for simulation-specific preprocessing.

use_giÔÉÅ

If True, grounded iceberg landmask is used during processing.

Type:

bool

Examples

Basic usage (single timestep):

>>> from datetime import datetime
>>> proc = FastIceProcessor("Rothrock")
>>> ds = proc.process_window(datetime(1994, 9, 8), save_zarr=False)

Batch processing over time:

The FastIceProcessor is typically run in a loop using a driver script such as [compute_fast_ice.py](https://github.com/dpath2o/AFIM/blob/main/src/python/compute_fast_ice.py):

python: from datetime import datetime, timedelta from fast_ice_processor import FastIceProcessor

dt_start = datetime(1993, 1, 1) dt_end = datetime(1999, 12, 31) proc = FastIceProcessor(‚ÄúRothrock‚Äù, roll_win=15) current_date = dt_start + timedelta(days=15)

while current_date <= dt_end - timedelta(days=15):

proc.process_window(current_date) current_date += timedelta(days=15)

For more, see the full project repository: üîó https://github.com/dpath2o/AFIM

Apply fast ice masking based on thresholds for concentration and velocity.

compute_fast_ice_outputs(roll_mask_vars)[source]ÔÉÅ

Compute fast ice metrics: 1D, 2D, and 3D outputs for spatial and temporal aggregation.

This method is the backbone of the class and is intended to be called by process_window().

Parameters:

roll_mask_vars (dict of xarray.DataArray) ‚Äì Masked variables used for final computations.

Returns:

Final dataset with all fast ice metrics.

Return type:

xarray.Dataset

compute_rolling_averages(ds)[source]ÔÉÅ

Compute rolling averages over time for each fast ice-related variable.

Parameters:

ds (xarray.Dataset) ‚Äì Dataset of raw model fields.

Returns:

Dictionary with variable names as keys and rolling-averaged DataArrays as values.

Return type:

dict of xarray.DataArray

process_window(dtC, hemisphere='south', ow_zarrs=False, save_zarrs=True)[source]ÔÉÅ

Main entry point to process fast ice metrics for a single central date.

Parameters:

  • dtC (datetime) ‚Äì Central date for the rolling window.

  • hemisphere (str) ‚Äì Hemisphere to process (‚Äònorth‚Äô or ‚Äòsouth‚Äô).

  • ow_zarrs (bool) ‚Äì Overwrite existing Zarr file if True.

  • save_zarr (bool) ‚Äì Save result to disk as a Zarr dataset if True.

Returns:

Fast ice dataset containing all computed metrics.

Return type:

xarray.Dataset
